subSections.title: Glyph origin
subSections.text:
{{Han etyl}}
{{Han compound|女|子|t1=woman|t2=child|ls=ic}}.

The widely accepted meaning of this character is that the characters for "female" ({{l|zh|女}}) and "child" ({{l|zh|子}}) were put together to form a compound because it was good for a woman to have a child. Similarly, it has been proposed that the compound originally refers to the mutual affection between the mother and child, which then extended to mean "good". These theories are supported by the smaller {{l|zh|子}} found in some oracle bones and bronze inscriptions.

However, broader interpretations of the second character {{l|zh|子}} could lead to other theories. {{l|zh|子}} could also mean "son", so it may have meant two children, a boy and a girl next to each other, which is a good fortune to have a boy and a girl. {{l|zh|子}} could also mean "man", so it may have referred to the love between a man and a woman, which is good. {{w|Duan Yucai}}, in his annotated version of ''{{w|Shuowen}}'', interpreted it as originally referring to the beauty of {{zh-l|女子|woman}}. Lastly, it could mean that the "attitude" of a girl was considered good.

subSections.title: Etymology
subSections.text:
The two pronunciations are cognate – pronunciation 2 is the ''*-s'' suffixed form, or exoactive/putative of pronunciation 1, literally "to consider good". Compare {{och-l|惡|id=3|[[bad]]; [[evil]]}} > {{och-l|惡|id=2|to consider [[bad]]; to [[hate]]}}.

This word has been compared with {{inh|zh|sit-pro|*hu||to raise; to rear; to nourish}}: Proto-Lolo-Burmese *''hu<sup>3</sup>'', Abor-Miri ''u'', Qiang (Mawo) ''χu'', which is only attested in a limited number of languages. If this is correct, it may be related to {{och-l|畜|to raise; to rear; domesticated animal}}. Alternatively, compare {{cog|bo|མཁོ||necessary, important}}.

Cognate with {{cog|bca|hux||good}}, which may be a loanword from Chinese.
